Expectation1: Communicate with clients and vendors regarding financial matters.
Situation1: A client has an inquiry about a specific line item on their most recent invoice.
Expectation2: Teach Torah and Jewish law to children and adults.
Situation2: The weekly required religious school class for children is set to occur.
Story: I stared at the blinking cursor on my computer screen, rereading the client’s email for the third time. They wanted clarification on a confusing line item from their latest invoice, and I knew I needed to respond quickly and clearly—my reputation as an accountant depended on it. But as I started drafting my reply, my phone buzzed with a reminder: the children’s Torah class was about to begin. As their rabbi, I was expected to be present, to guide them through the week’s parsha, to answer their questions with patience and warmth. I could picture their eager faces waiting for me in the classroom, their parents trusting me to nurture their children’s Jewish learning. My heart pounded as I weighed the urgency of the client’s financial concern against the sacred responsibility of teaching Torah. Both roles demanded my full attention, both were non-negotiable in their own way. I felt the tension coil inside me, torn between the numbers on my screen and the lessons waiting to be shared.
